conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the interval from 0 to 10 seconds is greater than or less than 100 meters, we need to calculate the area under the velocity-time graph for this interval.
The area under the graph represents the displacement (distance fallen) because displacement is the integral of velocity with respect to time.

The velocity-time graph is shown as a curve starting at v = 0 m/s at t = 0 s, increasing to v = 20 m/s at t = 10 s. The graph forms a triangular-like shape during the interval from t = 0 s to t = 10 s.
The area under the curve can be approximated as the area of a triangle because the velocity increases linearly (approximately) with time.
The formula for the area of a triangle is: Area = (1/2) × base × height.
The base of the triangle corresponds to the time interval, which is 10 s.
The height of the triangle corresponds to the maximum velocity, which is 20 m/s.
Substitute the values into the formula: Area = (1/2) × 10 s × 20 m/s.
The area under the curve represents the distance fallen during the interval from t = 0 s to t = 10 s. The calculated area is 100 m.
The distance fallen during the interval from t = 0 s to t = 10 s is exactly 100 meters. Therefore, it is neither greater nor less than 100 meters; it is equal to 100 meters.
